html:
Matière Première Architecture, a studio located in the Eastern Townships of Quebec, has designed a minimalist office complex within a scenic, forested site that blends residential architectural elements with commercial functionality.

Called Atelier Matière Première – Nu Drom, the project was made to house Matière Première Architecture and its sister company Nu Drom, a construction firm. The site is located at the gateway of the town of Magog. The two buildings that comprise the project were designed by Matière Première Architecture and constructed simultaneously by Nu Drom. 

One structure is dedicated to artisanal production, while the other was conceived as a space for work, reflection, and public engagement. Together, both spaces were envisioned as part of a unified architectural ensemble, united in both materiality and placement.

For this project, the architects paid careful attention to both the natural and cultural heritage of the region. “Designing here meant listening first—listening to the land, to the site’s history, and to our own needs as creators,” said Matière Première Architecture co-founder, Etienne Chausse.

The office building was conceived as an evolving showcase for the studio’s creative practice. Carefully placed floor-to-ceiling windows create subtle plays of light that shift with the hours and seasons. This helps ensure that no two experiences within the spaces feel the same. Additionally, the white cedar cladding, left untreated, will develop a silvery patina over time.

Landscape design was a critical component of the project. The site’s natural character was preserved, with large portions of the terrain left untouched. A visual and sensory buffer between the building and the natural terrain was achieved through the use of low concrete planters filled with grasses and conifers, as well as carefully placed paving.

Inside, the design balances openness and intimacy. The public spaces on the ground floor are linked to the above creative studio through a sculptural staircase in folded steel, topped with oak. 

Flexibility also drove the interior layout. The ground floor, which is currently used as a showroom, was designed to easily convert into additional office space as needs change.

Thermal comfort and daylight performance guided decisions from early in the design process. The glazed façades, which are strategically oriented, help regulate indoor temperature, while maximizing natural light intake. 

On the southern elevation, the glass wall is deliberately recessed from the building envelope, creating a thermal buffer that limits solar heat gain in the summer, while enhancing passive heat in the winter.

To the west, an exterior timber screen filters low-angle afternoon sunlight, providing visual comfort without disrupting the connection to the landscape. With this project, natural light is treated as a living material, and the integration of passive strategies helps create spaces that are both comfortable and inspiring.
